Award.AwardTitle: Identifying an Effective and Scalable Model of Lesson Study

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project investigates the variation in teachers' practice of lesson study to identify effective and scalable design features of lesson study associated with student mathematics achievement growth in Florida. Lesson study is a teacher professional development model in which a group of teachers works collaboratively to plan a lesson, observe the lesson in a classroom with students, and analyze and discuss the student work and understanding in response to the lesson. Florida is the first state to promote lesson study as a statewide professional development model for implementing the Common Core State Standards for Mathematics and improving instruction and student achievement. The original lesson study model imported from Japan poses a challenge for implementation and scalability in the United States, and there is emerging evidence that modifications have been made to make it feasible within the constraints of teachers' work schedules and school structures. Thus, there is an urgent need to investigate the variation in lesson study practice and how modified design features of mathematics lesson study are associated with improvement of student mathematics achievement. The research team will conduct a statewide survey of approximately 1,000 teachers in grades 3-8 who are practicing mathematics lesson study during the 2015-2016 academic year. They will examine variations in four design features of lesson study (structure, facilitator, knowledge resources for lesson planning, and research lesson and discussion) and their associated organizational supports. They will examine the relationships between these design features and the original lesson study model, teacher learning, and students' mathematics achievement growth.

This project is designed to advance the scholarship and practice of lesson study by: (1) identifying an effective and scalable model of mathematics lesson study with specific design features that are associated with positive teacher learning experience and improved student mathematics achievement; (2) advancing practical knowledge on how this effective and scalable model of mathematics lesson study can be practiced, based on in-depth case studies of lesson study groups; and (3) contributing to teacher learning principles that can be applied to various professional development programs in mathematics. The project will disseminate evidence regarding the characteristics of an effective and scalable mathematics lesson study model to state and district-level facilitators across the country. The project will also develop a Florida Lesson Study Network (FLSN) to share resources and facilitate communications regarding lesson study practice.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objectives of this DRK-12 exploratory project are to investigate the variation in teachers’ practice of lesson study and identify effective and scalable design features of lesson study associated with effective teacher learning and student mathematics achievement growth in Florida. Lesson study is a teacher-driven, collaborative, inquiry-based process of instructional improvement in which a group of teachers studies standards, curriculum, instruction, and student learning, develops a lesson with a student learning goal, experiments with the lesson in a classroom, and discusses the effectiveness of instruction for deepening students’ conceptual understanding and procedural fluency. The Florida Department of Education imported this international innovation from Japan as a teacher professional development model and has promoted lesson study statewide since 2010 to implement the Common Core State Standards using federal Race to the Top (RTTT) funding.   

 

The project team conducted: (1) a longitudinal statewide survey of district professional development coordinators in 45 districts in 2014, 2015, and 2016 as well as interviews of select districts, (2) a teacher and facilitator survey of lesson study practices in 2016, and (3) case studies of lesson study groups in 2015 and 2016. 

 

District survey data showed a major variation in the level of implementation and sustainability of lesson study across the state. We found that 40% (18 out of 45 districts) of the districts successfully sustained lesson study two years after the RTTT funding ended in 2014. These districts sustained lesson study by first internalizing lesson study through communicating and funding a district-wide expectation of job-embedded, inquiry-based professional development. Following this internalization, district leaders institutionalized lesson study by supporting school ownership and leadership in organizing and embedding lesson study into the school organizational structures and routines. In addition, the districts that sustained lesson study were more likely to report increased teacher effectiveness in improving student achievement as measured by school mean teacher value-added scores in mathematics.

 

Teacher survey data were analyzed to examine the relationship among three design features of lesson study (duration, facilitator orientation, material quality), teacher participation in an effective inquiry process, and teacher learning outcomes. We found that facilitators’ focus on student thinking, the quality of materials, and the duration of lesson study were significantly associated with teacher participation in an effective inquiry process, which in turn is associated with perceived positive changes in teacher knowledge, self-efficacy, and expectation. Among these three design features, facilitators’ focus on student thinking was most strongly associated with positive teacher outcomes.

 

Using the case study data, we further explored the nature of lesson study processes that deepen teacher learning and students’ mathematical understanding in two studies. In the first study, we contrasted two lesson study groups’ meeting and teaching data to illustrate how prioritizing different student knowledge types (i.e., procedural and conceptual knowledge), on either a superficial or deep level, promoted different teacher and student learning. We found that one group’s balanced foci on procedural and conceptual knowledge on both deep and superficial levels allowed students to explain their reasoning for solving a given problem, while the other group’s focus on procedural knowledge on a superficial level led to a teacher-centered instruction that guided students to the correct answer with few opportunities for argumentation and deeper reasoning.

 

In the second study, we analyzed one lesson study group’s work carefully to illustrate how teachers used the lesson study process to facilitate student discussion in the research lesson without reducing students’ cognitive engagement (i.e., interpreting, analyzing, and synthesizing, instead of merely memorizing and replicating)—thereby successfully maintaining a high cognitive demand level. We found that thoroughly anticipating various student responses, unpacking the mathematical concept to understand and guide student thinking, and planning a lesson focusing on detailed facilitation practices allowed the group to maintain a high cognitive demand level during the research lesson and support students’ deeper mathematical understanding. 

 

Collectively, the findings from this project demonstrate the promise of lesson study as a teacher-driven, collaborative, and inquiry-based process for improving teacher learning and student learning. This is especially the case when the facilitator focuses teachers’ inquiry and discussion on student thinking, when the group manages to focus on both conceptual and procedural knowledge development of students, and when lesson study is used to plan a lesson that maintains a high cognitive demand level. School districts play a crucial role for teachers to continuously engage in lesson study since the effective design features of lesson study—longer duration, development of effective teacher leaders who facilitate in-depth discussions of student thinking and instructional practice, and high quality instructional materials—require district-level resources and commitment to support teacher engagement in lesson study.
